description:
Corvus kubaryi, commonly known as the Mariana Crow, is a species of crow endemic to the Mariana Islands in the western Pacific Ocean. It is a medium-sized corvid, typically measuring around 46-53 cm in length and weighing between 400-600 grams.

The Mariana Crow has a predominantly black plumage with a distinctive purplish-blue sheen on its wings and tail. Its bill is strong and slightly curved, and its feet are large and adapted for perching and hopping. The species is known for its high-pitched, repeated calls, which are often described as a "kraw-kraw-kraw" sound.

Corvus kubaryi is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of foods, including insects, small vertebrates, fruits, and carrion. It plays an important role in the local ecosystem as a seed disperser and scavenger.

The Mariana Crow is classified as a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) due to habitat loss, predation by introduced species, and the effects of typhoons and other natural disasters. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique and ecologically significant corvid species.
